posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
So many of you know my reluctance (to put it mildly) to put Paladin and Rogue levels together.

I have been thinking about this.

In PnP, I think things are a bit more concrete (especially 3.0) and there are valid reasons against putting these two Classes together.  One of them is the fact that there are other classes that have access to UMD and Tumble that do not have Sneak Attack.

In NWN, however, we do not have this luxury.  There is only Rogue, Bard, and Assassin.  And of these three, only Rogue is a possibility without an alignment change.

So it is with a heavy RP heart that I say that Rogue and Pally combinations should be considered valid combinations in NWN.

Of course, should one be playing in an altered environment where one can get Tumble and UMD without Sneak Attack (the PRC, for example) then it should be avoided.

Your comments and opinions are welcome.

posts.author: webshaman1

It's more about how NWN has made access to UMD and Tumble a 3 class show and gimped certain Classes (by this I mean both skills in one class).

In the PnP version (3.0), one really doesn't have this conundrum.

Knockdown is purely a NWN creation - the feat itself does not exist in PnP.  That it is a "select at will" action, I really do not have a problem with it.

As for UMD and Tumble (at least one can get cross-class tumble) these are skill things, not feats (but you know that).

I am aware of the Tumble thing, of course.

With the limitation as well of 3 Classes per build (max amount one can have), which also does not exist in PnP, this makes the equation even more sordid.  Getting things "squeezed in" is a fundamental part of building in NWN - and with such limitations as the above, we have to make sacrifices for playability imo.

I wish we had more options, more class slots, etc.  But we do not.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
The absence of any lore or rule is difficult to prove but sure, I can give it a go.

3.0 and 3.5 were the move away from the Lawful Stupid characters including Paladin to the a more dynamic Lawful Good including paladins and their code of conduct.

With the move to 3.0 we see backstab being replaced with sneak attack which is a combat ability just like knockdown or disarm. With the move to 3.5 we see pickpocket being replaced with sleight of hand. Each of these is to bring the class skill/feat descriptions more inline with the class alignment positioning and multiclassing options. Things like backstab and pickpocket have negative connotations, giving rise incidentally to positioning like this thread. These are corrected in 3.0 and 3.5.

Edition 3.0 / 3.5 (NwN & Expansions source)
Players handbook 3.0 and 3.5
- nothing under paladin indicating it cannot take rogue as a multiclass
- nothing under the paladins code of conduct indicating anything related to rogue skills or abilities, or rogues
- nothing under rogue indicating it is a non-lawful or non-good class nor anything indicating that a rogue cannot use their abilities if they are lawful and or good. In fact it specifically states they can be any alignment.
- nothing under sneak attack indicating it is a non lawful nor non good attack, blends in well with the fact rogues can be lawful good. It is just an attack that leverages the vulnerabilities of your opponents body to do more damage.
- nothing under pick pocket indicating it is an evil or even neutral act. This falls well in line with the fact that rogues can be lawful good

DMs guide 3.0 and 3.5
- nothing about incompatibilities between rogue and paladin or lawful good and rogue skills. Nothing indicating any incompatibilities between paladin code of conduct and rogue abilities.

Book of Exalted deeds 3.5
- nothing indicating rogue abilities are not in line with a lawful good alignment or a paladins code of conduct.
- exalted rogue states as fact/ specific ruling that a lawful good rogue is “as dependable as a paladin” and sneak attack as no “more evil than bull rush or trampling attacks” or any other form of violence. It is all in how you apply the violence. It also makes reference to the lawful stupid code of honor as not limiting the lawful good rogue.


That should probably do it.

As I said, nothing in rules or lore stating it is not an acceptable combination.

Fact ... not opinions stated as fact with no references.

And, I want to call this out, I stated my opinion, you countered with what I believed was a made up fact, I again countered with my opinion (belief) and indicated is bad form to use “fact” in a discussion without backing it up with some proof. The important bit here is that you introduced it and positioned it as fact. Fair enough, but it is also fair .. I think .. that if you are going to claim you win a discussion with an unsubstantiated fact, that it is then your responsibility to do your own work and substantiate it. Making it my job to prove/disprove your unsubstantiated fact is counter productive to a discussion and bad form. Otherwise we fall into the internet discussion with everyone tossing around opinions not so cleverly disguised as unsubstantiated “facts” and I hope that does not happen here. It takes significant effort to disprove what someone else can claim as a fact with no effort whatsoever.

Update: a point of clarification. Lawful Stupid is a cultural term hailing back to a time when players and DMs interpreted a Paladin code of conduct so rigidly it impacted the ability to play dynamic characters properly. It was a common term for people and or campaigns that played Paladins ... poorly.

This was understood as an issue and corrected as subsequent editions were released. Offering a more dynamic paladin including non human paladins, paladins with different (individual) code of conducts and ultimately non good Paladins.

It was not meant as a derogatory argument attack. It is an actual cultural term and real issue at the time.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
With respect to PnP Rogue Paladins multiclass has never been discouraged. With respect to NwN, UMD is a pretty powerful thing in most modules.

On Arelith, which has provided substantial class and balance customisations they made some interesting changes. There are other persistent modules I have played with more class customisations but they all tended to abandon the balance.

First, they made bards allowed to be lawful, this resulted in every spell caster dipping bard and every melee dipping rogue. From a balance perspective it worked. From a RP perspective, on an RP heavy persistent module, it really didn’t. Nobody RPd their bard dips and it felt odd having to “be a bard” as a cleric for example.

Bard paladins were fun though, brought a light hearted approach to Paladins, the slang term for them is Bardadin if you were curious.

They then introduced a generic class called specialist with no RP connotations. Which I think solved the issue elegantly. All those bard dips could be specialist dips and still net UMD.

Rogue was never a big deal really, rogue has always been positioned as a pretty generic multi-class with whatever and go class requiring no RP elements unless you decide to create some around it. They can be scallywags, politicians, underworld figures, Robin Hood, the joker, etc. They actually get, in my opinion if not fact, the widest possible RP breadth in PnP.

So, I understand it is easy to speak for another's motivations and position, I consider it a weak argument and pretty insulting to essentially state both sides of the argument speaking for both people in an attempt to validate a weak and/or untenable position.  I also understand how easy it is to provide a small piece of the context and argue to that rather than the entire thing and addressing it as a whole.  As I understand how easy it is to claim rules exist, lists of things exist, ruling on combinations that oppose the basic mechanics of both the PnP and NwN games exist.  This is excellent, and a basis for a discuission, but you have to actually provide them.  This is why I provide actual references and back up my statements because without the actual backup, the points have no merit no matter how many times you claim them as fact.

Alternatively lets have a hypothetical discussion about why you feel the game mechanics are wrong.  It would be an interesting discussion I am certain.

Finally, I do not need to nor wish to stoop to the level of speaking on behalf of and to the motivation of another person in the discussion, it is not particularly difficult I just find it distasteful and petty.    I prefer to discuss the facts on their own merits rather than speaking for you, I would ask you to do the me the same courtesy.

posts.content:
Let us talk Code of Conduct for a moment.

I wanted to keep this separate from my response to Webshaman but I believe it is an important thing.

In 3.0 and 3.5 and moving forward, many barriers to rigid RP were removed.  I noted this early with the shift in feat/skill naming and descriptions.  

One of the Paladin specific interesting things  was the idea of a Code of Conduct.  The position in this thread is based upon an idea of a universal "Code of Conduct" which all Paladins must follow and implies it is a rigid , unbending thing that requires a Paladin to behave in a way that bypasses even the base core rules as outlined in the system.  I refer to this by the cultural reference of the time ... the Lawful Stupid Paladin and this is something that has been specifically addressed/dismantled in 3e and moving forward.

There are a few references to Code of Conduct in the Players Handbook.
Reference: Player's Handbook 3e
Paladin References:
Alignment: Paladins must be lawful good, and they lose their
divine powers if they deviate from that alignment. Additionally,
paladins swear to follow a code of conduct that is in line with lawfulness
and goodness.

A paladin must be of lawful good alignment
and loses all class abilities if she ever willingly commits an evil act.
Additionally, a paladin’s code requires that she respect legitimate
authority, act with honor (not lying, not cheating, not using poison,
and so forth), help those in need (provided they do not use the help
for evil or chaotic ends), and punish those who harm or threaten
innocents.

Generic "Lawful Evil" Villain reference:
Lawful Evil, “Dominator”: A
lawful evil villain methodically takes
what he wants within the limits of his
code of conduct without regard for
whom it hurts. He cares about
tradition, loyalty, and order but not
about freedom, dignity, or life. He
plays by the rules but without mercy
or compassion. ... this is a snippet from a full paragraph

Ex-Cleric reference:
A cleric who grossly violates the code of conduct required by his god
(generally by acting in ways opposed to the god’s alignment or
purposes) loses all spells and class features, except for armor and
shield proficiencies and proficiency with simple weapons. He
cannot thereafter gain levels as a cleric of that god until he atones
(see the atonement spell description, page 201).

I have always seen the "Code of Conduct" as a thing that defines a divine character, well any character really as you see there is a call out for a Villain above, but ... in the case of the Divine characters it gets even more interesting for me.

A "Code of Conduct" is both a rigid and flexible thing.  It is rigid because in the case of a Divine character it is ... usually ... tied directly to a Deity and a particular alignment limitation, portfolio(s), goal(s), opposing Dieties, Friendly Dieties, Deity particular hatred, etc. 

Clerics I have always seen as the more rigid Divine class, they draw their power from worshipping a specific Deity and buying into that Deities "stuff", they are human and they make mistakes and if they are bad enough ... Ex-Cleric but they do get an alignment range or some wiggle room.

Paladin's add something even more interesting to mixture in 3e.  A Paladin is not tied to a specific Deity, a Paladin is a force of divine righteousness with their own individually specific "Code of Conduct" not necessarily tied to a specific Deity and/or Deities it is derived simply from their belief in their own Righteousness.

Reference Players Handbook 3e:

Religion: Paladins need not devote themselves to a
single deity—devotion to righteousness is enough. Those
who align themselves with particular religions prefer
Heironeous (god of valor) over all others, but some paladins
follow Pelor (the sun god). Paladins devoted to a god are
scrupulous in observing religious duties and are welcome in
every associated temple.
 

This, offers immense RP opportunity and versatility.  I feel people easily get stuck in a narrow idea of what a Paladin is, perhaps even seeing them as an even more restricted version of a cleric.

This is very much not the case.  A Paladin is a free entity working on the behalf of their righteous belief in their own particular version Lawfulness and Goodness.  They can and should do things Clerics cannot and should not do.  They can and should even do things that oppose their Deities as long as those things align with Lawfulness and Goodness.  It is a delicate balance between the Paladin's sense of divine mandate, their Deity or Deities and even the Laws of the place the live in.  In the end though, their Righteous belief sits at the top of the priority pile. 

There is no concept of "Code of Honor" that a Paladin has to follow in 3e.  There is an individually defined "Code of Conduct" as defined not by a Global definition for all Paladins nor a Deity but by the Paladin themselves and what defines their Righteous belief of what is Lawful and Good and what that represents.  You can "choose" to be Lawful Stupid but you are no longer "required" to be and that little difference makes all the difference in the world.  It still gives me a little rush of excitement about the PnP possibilities and what the represents each time I think about it.

Simply put, Paladin's as of 3e, gained even more individual character and RP flexibility than Clerics.  Lawful Stupid was put to bed firmly, Paladin's quite simply rock RP wise in 3.0e+
